messageBody:
Hi,
I am trying to understand the design patterns used in the JUnit
code. I noticed following piece of codes, which I am not quite sure
why it is written in such way. I hope some one can help me to explain
it.

So the TestRunner.java Run() ... cals TestSuite.java 's Run() which
in turns calls TestResult's method.


Notice that Run() does not directly call
test.RunBare() but instead, using anynomous class
and defined a protect() method in the class. And using runProtected
() method to invoked this method .

Protectable p= new Protectable() {
public void protect() throws Throwable {
test.runBare();
}
};
runProtected(test, p);

My question is why this written in such way ? Why not call
test.RunBare() directly ?

This does not same to have the reason to use Adaptor pattern
explained in the CookBook ?


Can some show me some insight on this ? Thank you.

Chester


in TestResult.java


/**
* Runs a TestCase.
*/
protected void run(final TestCase test) {
startTest(test);
Protectable p= new Protectable() {
public void protect() throws Throwable {
test.runBare();
}
};
runProtected(test, p);

endTest(test);
}
/**
* Runs a TestCase.
*/
public void runProtected(final Test test, Protectable p) {
try {
p.protect();
}
catch (AssertionFailedError e) {
addFailure(test, e);
}
catch (ThreadDeath e) { // don't catch ThreadDeath by
accident
throw e;
}
catch (Throwable e) {
addError(test, e);
}
}
